profileText: A Representative from Virginia; born in Blacksburg, Montgomery County, Va., June 14, 1814; attended private schools, and was graduated from Georgetown University, Washington, D.C.; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1838 and commenced practice in Salem, Va.; elected as a Democrat to the Thirty-first and to the five succeeding Congresses (March 4, 1849-March 3, 1861); chairman, Committee on Expenditures on Public Buildings (Thirty-third Congress); served in the Confederate Army as lieutenant colonel of the Fifty-fourth Virginia Regiment until 1862, when he was assigned to the command of the Twenty-seventh Virginia Cavalry; at the close of hostilities he resumed the practice of law, and subsequently, in 1880, engaged in agricultural pursuits; died at his home, ``Falling Waters,'' Shawsville, Montgomery County, Va., December 16, 1890; interment in Fotheringay Cemetery, Montgomery County, Va.

researchRecord.name: In the Edmundson Family Papers, 1795-1903, approximately 1,000 items.
n.d., 1 item.
researchRecord.description: An undated autograph of Henry Alonzo Edmundson from Salem, Roanoke County, Virginia.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1853, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Henry Alonzo Edmundson to President Franklin Pierce written on March 7, 1853. In the letter, Henry Edmundson recommends General Douglas B. Lane as a U.S. Marshal in Virginia.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1857, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Henry Alonzo Edmundson to Jacob Thompson written on written on March 11, 1857. In the letter, Henry Edmundson recommends the appointment of Fayette McMullin as Marshal of the District of Columbia.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.description: Other authors include Henry Alonzo Edmundson.
